column4: : Actually wanting to speak to to you about your package upgrade proposal. BTW, do use a different nick in #g-h? I have never seen you before
no, #g-h is also Mitario :)
: Ah. I see you now :-)
well, say wat you wan to say :)
: Ok. I have been wanting to create a new frontend for package upgrades. Synaptic is hideous and red-carpet is too enterprise specific. Something is needed. Yours is somewhat better
i'm just finishing a new draft of my proposal, i'll put it in my weblog ASAP
every idea is welcome of course
: But I do not see why a user would ever need to know about a system library. Whether to install it or upgrade it, he should never have to know what the hell libgnomeui is etc
: Any chance you are creating it with Mono? If so, I will happily help out
i'm creating my mockups with ruby, i have not yet decided which language i'm going to use for the real stuff
: They should only ever be presented with Application Names. Not sure if Linspire is similar, but it does sound like they do hide the cruft away
ah
but why woudn't you want to list libraries as an update?
I want to see the updates of all packages actually
: Why should someone be made aware that they have libgnomeui installed? Abiword ? Yes. libgnomeui? No
and why not, as a developer, I would be really pleased to know that for example libgnomeui is updated
: But are developers the Gnome target audience? (Well, kinda, but you know what I mean)
ok, say, my father, is a windows user, what is the harm that he know that libgnomeui is installed?
: But, maybe I misunderstood what you were aiming for. I want to do a replacement for synaptic that sane as well as have an update utility
: When he tries to install it, the package management app will retrieve it in the backaground
my first goal was to create a nice update installation thingy, not a replacement for the package manager :)
